content.text: Chapter one included a description on what data and information is. This chapter covers saving data in an organized manner.
content.description: Data refers to raw facts like numbers, words, images, symbols without meaning. Information is processed data that has meaning. Information is used to make decisions. A system is a collection of components that work together. The computer is a system.
content.example: A telephone book (manual) or a mobile phone (electronic) storing names and numbers. Storing data in a book is a manual database. Using a database ensures information is found quickly and easily (e.g., finding a phone number) compared to looking through a book.

content.definition: A collection of organized data can be defined as a database.
content.example: School library storing books (Title, Author, Subject, Number of copies). A student record book storing marks (Subject, Term, Grade).

content.text: Important features of a database are Minimal data redundancy, Data consistency, Increased efficiency, Increased accuracy, Increased validity, Increased security.

content.title: Minimal data redundancy
content.description: If the same data is stored in several tables, this is called data redundancy. Minimizing redundancy (e.g., storing Name only once in Student Table) reduces errors and inconsistency.

content.title: Data consistency
content.description: Minimizing redundancy ensures that same data is saved only once, maintaining data consistency (e.g., Name stored in Student Table, Marks in Marks Table).

content.title: Increased efficiency
content.description: Since data is properly organized, retrieving information (e.g., Student Name, Address, Grade) is fast. Deleting unnecessary data (e.g., Deleting a student from Student Table automatically deletes marks from Marks Table due to foreign keys).

content.title: Increased accuracy
content.description: Updating a name in one place (e.g., Student Table) updates marks automatically. This prevents errors due to multiple entries.

content.title: Increases validity
content.description: Properties of fields can be set at design (e.g., Fees >= 100). Validation ensures data is correct at the point of entry.

content.title: Increases security
content.description: Unauthorized access can be controlled by using a password and encrypting data. This increases security (e.g., Encrypting employee data to prevent unauthorized reading).
Comparison of manual and electronic databases based on features like efficiency, accuracy, space, security.

content.definition: A collection of fields related to one person or object. E.g., Name, Date of Birth.
A collection of fields is called a record.
A collection of records is called a data table.
A collection of related data tables.

content.title: Separating data into two tables
content.description: A student record book (Bio-data) is separated into Student Table and Marks Table to reduce data duplication. Name stored only in Student Table.

content.definition: A column (or combination of columns) which uniquely identifies a record is called primary key.
special_features: Example: Admission Number (Admission No), Book Number (Book No).
content.example: Student Table: Admission No is primary key. Book Table: Book Number is primary key.

content.text: The primary key which consists of two or more columns uniquely identifying a record is called composite primary key.
content.example: Year and Sport (e.g., 2013 Cricket) is a composite primary key as year and sport identify a unique record.

content.description: Identify primary key for Book Table.

content.definition: If a field (or fields) of one table can be used to uniquely identify rows of another table, these fields are called foreign keys. This key builds a connection between two tables.

examples: Admission No (FK of Marks Table) links to Admission No (PK of Student Table).

disadvantages_of_duplication: Inability to select a single primary key for maintaining identity of records.
Inability to analyze data properly (e.g., duplicate marks can lead to incorrect analysis).
Reduced efficiency (Entering data for multiple years repeatedly).
High possibility of getting inaccurate data (e.g., Mohommad Malakkar vs Mohommad Malakkar).
advantages_of_separation: Easy to update (One place update changes all related data).

relationships.name: One-to-one
relationships.description: One row in Table A is related to only one row in Table B. A row in Table B is related to one row in Table A. Example: Student (Student ID) related to Borrowed Book (Book No).

relationships.name: One-to-many
Each record in Table A related to several records in Table B. Example: Student (Student ID) related to Borrowed Books (Book No, Book No).
relationships.Note: A Student can borrow many books.
Relationship is built using Foreign Key.

content.name: Many-to-many
content.description: A record in Table A is related to several records in Table B. A record in Table B is related to several records in Table A.
content.example: Sports Table (Student No, Sport, Team No, Team Member Count). Each student can play many sports. Each sport has many students.
relationships: Student No (PK of Students Sports Table) links to Sport No (PK of Sports Table).
Team No (PK of Students Sports Table) is part of composite key of Sports Table (Student No + Sport No).

types.name: Numeric
types.description: Used for calculations. Examples: Integer (Whole numbers), Real (Decimals).

types.name: Text
types.description: Composed of letters, numbers or special chars. Used for names. E.g., NIC number, Phone number.

types.name: Date / Time
types.description: Date and Time formats. E.g., 12/23/2013, 7.35 AM

content.title: Creating Forms to Entering and Displaying Data

content.text: Forms are used to enter data into a table in Database Management Systems. Further, forms are used to display entered data as well.

details: Data entered into last column of table.
Data output via form (e.g., Display Name, Address).

actions: Create -> Form Design -> Add Existing Fields -> Show tables -> Select table -> Drag fields to form.

content.text: Let us use a query to obtain necessary information from the data of related tables.

content.code: SELECT Student No, Name, Email FROM Student, Marks WHERE Subject='ICT'.

content.description: Student No, Name, Email and Subject (ICT) are selected columns from Student Table. Subject column is filtered (WHERE Subject='ICT').
